sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: XT Ajax Framework is based on the following fundamental concepts:

listitem.para: Events
Handlers
Actions
Components
Responses

sect2.para: They work together in a simple processing flow:

listitem.para: Web pages fire events using standard JavaScript events.
Each event causes an Ajax request that is processed by simple Java objects acting as server side handlers.
The handler processes events creating actions.
Each action may render one or more HTML components in the page.
At the end, actions are canalised into an Ajax response sent back to the web page.

sect2.para: We'll take a more detailed look to each of the concepts above in the next section.

sect3.title: Ajax Events
sect3.para: In XT Ajax Framework you can raise events from your web pages as standard JavaScript events, and handle them by the server side, without having to write any javascript code. There are actually the following types of Ajax events:

listitem.para: Action events, a generic event type directly handled by configured handlers without calling any Spring MVC controller: this is most used for updating the web page with data from the server.

Submit events, a special type of event handled by configured handlers after executing the Spring MVC controller associated with the page: this event causes the submit of the page and so the handling of the submit by the controller, and can be used for further processing the submit for properly updating the view.

sect3.para: Ajax action events are fired in web pages as follows:
You have to simply call the (pre-implemented) doAjaxAction JavaScript function, passing:

listitem.para: The name (or id) of the event you want to fire ('eventId').
The html element which fired the event, through the this objects.
A JSON string containing extra parameters you want to pass to the server.

sect3.para: Once you receive the event in your server side handler, you can access the following information (see XT javadocs for more information):

listitem.para: The event id (corresponding to the event name above).
The Java HttpServletRequest object.
The name and id of the html element firing the event.
A map of string key/value pairs, containing the extra parameters defined above using the JSON string.
The command object created by the Spring MVC controller, if this is a BaseCommandController.

Once you receive the event in your server side handler, you can access the following information in addition to those defined above (see XT javadocs for more information):

listitem.para: A container of validation errors, for managing form submission errors.
The model map returned by the controller submit method, if any.

note.para: Given that submit events are handled after calling the configured Spring MVC controller, the command object, model map, and validation errors contained in the submit event are the same objects you manage in the controller.

You've seen how to fire events from web pages, and how to handle them through AjaxHandlers. The next step is how to associate events with handlers.

sect3.title: Associating events with handlers: the AjaxInterceptor
sect3.para: Once defined your events and implemented your handlers, you need to associate them.

For security reason, web pages events and ajax handlers are not automatically associated, nor can be globally associated. If it were so, malicious users could hack your JavaScript events and execute unwanted events.

So, events and handlers are associated per page path, that is, you have to configure every handler to manage events fired by a pre-determined, restricted, set of pages. Specifically, you can configure an handler to manage events fired by a specific, single, web page, or by web pages defined with Ant style pattern matching.
This is done in two simple steps.

First, you have to define in your Spring application context an AjaxInterceptor: it is the bean which associates web pages and Ajax handlers, making under the cover the actual event dispatching. Here is an example of AjaxInterceptor configuration:

The handlerMappings property is a list of key/value entries associating a web path (the key) with an handler (the value), which must be an AjaxHandler declared as a bean in the Spring applicationContext. As you can notice, the first entry associates the handler with an Ant style pattern, while others associate handlers with single pages. Doing so, you can also apply more handlers to the same group of pages. When more handlers apply to the same event, the one configured for matching the longest web path wins.

sect3.title: Ajax Actions
sect3.para: Ajax actions are created by handlers and act on the client: more specifically, they act on the web page that fired the event, interacting with its elements.

XT Ajax Framework provides many useful actions ready to be used (see the org.springmodules.xt.ajax.action package for details); however, creating custom actions is just a matter of implementing the following simple interface:
The execute() method is the one you call for producing the action result.
Actions can do various things, depending on the concrete implementation, but most of the time they will render components.

sect3.title: Identifying page parts
sect3.para: Ajax actions act on web pages, often interacting with page content: how do they identify page parts to interact with (i.e. for updating contents)?
They identify page parts by the HTML id attribute. So, you have to assign an id to every HTML element you want to interact with through Ajax actions:

sect3.title: Components
sect3.para: Generally speaking, components represent web page parts; however, most of the time they represent html elements, like input fields, tables and so. XT Ajax Framework provides many useful components ready to be used (see the org.springmodules.xt.ajax.component package for details), but creating custom components is just a matter of implementing the following simple interface:
Each component renders itself through the render() method, returning a string representation of its rendering.
But how do actions render components?
Components are added to actions in a way that depends on the concrete action implementation, and then rendered through the action execute() method.
Now that you have your ajax actions and components, the only thing left to do is filling your ajax response.

sect3.title: Ajax Response
sect3.para: AjaxResponse objects are filled with actions whose result is carried to clients, that is, to web pages. This is the interface of the AjaxResponse, followed by a description of its methods:

listitem.para: public String getResponse() : This method executes the added actions and returns their result.

sect3.para: In the context of an ajax response, actions are executed following their order of adding.

sect3.title: XT Ajax Framework, Taconite and integration with other JavaScript libraries
sect3.para: The way XT Ajax Framework interacts with client web pages is based on the wonderful Taconite JavaScript library. So, for using the XT Ajax Framework you need to include in your web pages Taconite, plus some other JavaScript library you can find under the js directory. However, all these core JavaScript libraries are put, at compile time, in the springxt.js file under the js/lib/core directory. This is the only file you need to include in your web page:

However, XT Ajax Framework integrates with other JavaScript libraries for providing additional capabilities, like new kind of actions: take a look at javadocs for more details. All these additional libraries can be found under the js/lib/opt directory.

tip.para: Under the js/lib/core you'll find also a springxt-min.js file: it is a minified version of springxt.js you can include in your pages for reducing the download size.

sect2.title: Tutorials
sect2.para: In this section we'll show you, by practical, step-by-step tutorials, how to work with XT Ajax Framework. All tutorials are based on XT Ajax samples: check out them if you want to take a look at the full source code.

sect3.title: Working with Ajax submit events.
sect3.para: Ajax submit events are used for updating pages after submitting data to your Spring MVC controllers.
